@magredana, I read the Audio. What i would like to know is what is the difference between DTS 1509k, and DD 5.1.. Sorry but when it comes to all this, I'm not sure what it means.

@Chi2is

Hmmm, I THINK what you are asking is what is the difference between the DTS here @1500 and FULL HD Audio, right?  In other words NOT DD 5.1 but you mean HD 5.1, right?

IF that is so, then the DTS is the 'core' of the HD Audio and it is almost always @1500.  Whereas FULL HD Audio is completely LOSSLESS and not compressed at all, say like Dolby 5.1 @640.  HD Audio tracks vary with different releases, but usually I think they can be anywhere around @3000-4000.  For example in a normal 2 hour movie the DTS track would take up maybe 1 Gig or so.  Whereas the full HD track could take up 3-4 Gigs, thus the LOSSLESS quality. 

But, with all that said, usually the DTS is quite good and MUCH MUCH better than what you normally would find on a DVD which would be Dolby @364-640 or so.

I hope that helps...
Would love to see a full BD, if possible.

@TheLathe and cl2is:

TheLathe - nice try but you are a bit confused, and you've confused some people here too. The main difference between DTS 5.1 and DD 5.1 is the bitrate. Bitrate is how much information in the track is being delivered per second. DTS is over TWICE the bitrate that DD (Dolby Digital) is, 1500kbps vs 640kbps. DD 5.1 is therefore AUDIBLY INFERIOR because it is lower bitrate. So always look for DTS 5.1 tracks, they sound noticeably cleaner, surround sounds better, bass is tighter too.
